summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the proposed protective order in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The government opposes two specific modifications requested by the defense: (1) allowing the defense to publicly name victims who have spoken publicly about Epstein or Maxwell in any forum, and (2) imposing restrictions on the government's use of its own investigative materials. The government argues these requests lack legal basis and would harm victims' privacy.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) who is seeking modifications to the protective order.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased co-conspirator; the case involves victims of sexual abuse by Epstein and Maxwell.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom this letter is addressed.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The government attorney who signed and submitted this letter.

connections.description: Maxwell is accused of facilitating Epstein's sexual abuse of minors; the case relates to their joint criminal activity.
Strauss, as AUSA, is prosecuting Maxwell in this criminal case.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and will rule on the protective order.

events.title: Defense Submission on Protective Order
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team submitted a letter and proposed protective order seeking modifications.

events.title: Government Response to Defense
events.description: The government filed this letter opposing Maxwell's requested modifications to the protective order.

events.title: Epstein Prosecution and Suicide
events.description: Reference to the prior criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein (19 Cr. 490) which was dismissed after his suicide.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government strongly opposes allowing the defense to publicly name victims who have ever spoken about Epstein or Maxwell in any public forum, calling the request 'extraordinarily broad, unnecessary, and inappropriate.'
The government argues victim privacy is protected by the Crime Victims' Rights Act and that public identification could deter other victims from coming forward.

The defense's proposed order would allow naming victims based on any past public statement (e.g., social media, podcasts), which the government says victims could not have anticipated would be used in this case.
The government also opposes the defense's request to restrict how the government uses its own investigative documents with witnesses, calling it unprecedented and without legal basis.

The government states its proposed order already allows the defense to reference victim names in sealed filings, in private investigative conversations, and for victims who have chosen to be publicly identified in *this* case.
